awd_titl_txt: First-principles design of strongly anharmonic crystalline solids with ultra-low lattice thermal conductivity
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational research and education to advance predictive modeling of thermal transport properties of insulating and semiconducting materials. Fossil fuels (petroleum, coal, and natural gas) account for the vast majority of the energy use in the world. Less than 1/3 of the total energy content is used productively, while the rest is rejected, mainly in the form of waste heat. In the US alone, the amount of this wasted energy is roughly equivalent to that contained in 400 billion gallons of gasoline. Many technologies for improving energy efficiency, or reusing the waste heat, depend on the availability of thermally insulating ceramics and semiconductors. For instance, thermoelectrics convert heat into electricity via a phenomenon called the Seebeck effect, which operates between a hot and a cold electrode. High-performance thermoelectric devices require materials that are poor conductors of heat but efficient conductors of electricity. Currently, few such materials are known, which prevents a wider adoption of this energy-saving technology. Similarly, better ceramic thermal insulators would save energy by enabling increased operating temperatures in combustion engines.

Heat in nonmetallic crystals is conducted by atomic vibrations, such as sound waves. Conventional semiconductors (e.g. silicon) are poor thermal insulators because these waves propagate independently of each other and encounter little resistance. Empirical methods for decreasing thermal conductivity aim to impede the forward movement of vibrational waves. However, these approaches require complex preparation methods and are often limited in efficiency. The PI and his group will design materials that have intrinsically low thermal conductivity because the heat-carrying waves of atomic vibrations scatter off of each other. In select solids, this scattering can become so strong that the flow of heat reaches the lowest possible value associated with glasses and amorphous solids. The project will advance computational techniques and quantum mechanical concepts for identifying and deliberately creating thermally insulating solids with desired properties.

The broader impacts of the proposed research are several-fold, involving broad dissemination of research results, education of graduate students in a rich multidisciplinary environment, and introduction of undergraduate students to modern computational methods. Successful completion of this research program will contribute to the development of new thermally insulating materials as thermoelectrics and coatings with potential benefits in energy conservation. The calculated thermal properties will be disseminated to the scientific and technical community by partnering with existing online databases of computed materials data.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports research and education to advance predictive modeling of thermal transport properties of crystalline insulators and semiconductors via the development of computational methods and theoretical concepts for lowering lattice thermal conductivity. The PI and his group are mainly interested in strongly anharmonic solids where intrinsic phonon-phonon interactions limit thermal conductivity to values near the amorphous limit; such materials are of interest in energy conservation and waste-heat recovery as ceramic coatings and thermoelectrics. The PI's quantum-mechanics-based design strategy involves the use of lone-pair electrons that host anharmonic bonds, oxides, and oxosulfides of transition-metals that host strong p-d electronic hybridization effects, high-symmetry solids with ions near electronic Jahn-Teller instabilities, and compounds with frustrated structural coordination. These approaches are based on fundamental principles for enhancing intrinsic phonon scattering in crystalline materials via a mechanism that is independent of processing, impurities, and grain structure. This will allow the attainment of minimal lattice thermal conductivity in bulk oxides and semiconductors.

To enable accurate computation of thermal properties, the group will pursue the following theoretical developments: (1) compressive-sensing-based methods for building lattice dynamical Hamiltonians for compositionally disordered materials, (2) efficient path integral molecular dynamics techniques for calculating low-temperature thermal transport properties of strongly anharmonic solids, and (3) electronic structure techniques for treating adiabatic lattice dynamics of solids with competing orbital ordering states in partially filled d-and f-electron shells. These methods will form a comprehensive suite of computational techniques for first-principles studies of thermal transport in anharmonic solids.

The proposed work is expected to improve fundamental understanding of the thermal transport properties of strongly anharmonic materials, advance the theory and software tools for modeling thermal transport properties of solids, and provide a theoretical basis for rational design of materials with low thermal conductivity. 

The broader impacts of the proposed research are several-fold, involving broad dissemination of research results, education of graduate students in a rich multidisciplinary environment, and introduction of undergraduate students to modern computational methods. Successful completion of this research program will contribute to the development of new thermally insulating materials as thermoelectrics and coatings with potential benefits in energy conservation. The calculated thermal properties will be disseminated to the scientific and technical community by partnering with existing online databases of computed materials data.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project are to advance a predictive theory and develop computational methods for calculating thermal and thermoelectric properties of materials. A major area of focus is how to obtain materials with very low thermal conductivity. Such materials are of interest as efficient thermoelectrics for converting waste heat into electricity, as well as ceramic coatings for insulating metals from hot exhaust gases in gas turbines and jet engines. Lattice contribution to thermal conductivity, which is mediated by modes of lattice vibrations (phonons), plays a dominant role in these applications. In most materials (e.g. crystalline silicon), phonons are relatively free to propagate over long distances without encountering any obstacles. As a result, such materials are good thermal conductors. We are interested in crystalline materials where phonons have so many obstacles that the thermal conductivity drops to very low values which approach the so-called amorphous or glass limit. We focus on cases where the interatomic bonds between atoms are strongly anharmonic, i.e., such that they create very strong interactions between individual phonon modes. These interactions tangle up and scatter phonons, inhibiting their propagation. We have shown how scattering processes involving 3 and 4 phonons are responsible for the ultralow thermal conductivities of many such materials, for instance Tl3VSe4  and the thermoelectric Earth-abundant mineral tetrahedrite (Cu12Sb4S13). We also showed that “non-diagonal” corrections to the usual phonon picture of thermal conductivity were important for tetrahedrite, where energy transfer between different phonon modes contributes significantly to thermal conductivity.

 

Another widely used method to make thermally insulting crystals is by introducing structural disorder, such as vacancies (sites with missing atoms) or by mixing with other elements; a typical example is Si-Ge alloy thermoelectrics to lower the thermal conductivity of pure Si. To meet the dearth of accurate computational approaches for treating disorder in crystals, we have developed a lattice dynamics method based on our compressive sensing approach, called vibrational cluster expansion (VCE). Our results for Pb(Te-Se) alloys show that, in contrast to previous approaches which produce large qualitative errors in the predicted thermal conductivities, our method agrees very well with experimental data. Adoption of this approach will enable scientists to study thermal properties of other technologically important systems.

 

In addition to ultralow thermal conductivity, efficient thermoelectrics should possess high power factors, which describe the ability to generate large electrical current from a temperature difference. In semiconductors and metals, charge carriers (electrons and holes) participate in thermal current flowing from the hot to the cold end. There are two contributions to this current: high-energy carriers more from the hot to the cold end, while low-energy carriers move in the opposite direction. Both result in the cooling of the hot electrode, but they carry electrical charge in opposite directions. Since usually these two opposite-flowing currents are approximately equal in magnitude, they cancel each other and there is only a small overall current. As a result, most materials show poor thermoelectric performance. High thermoelectric performance is attained when one of these currents is much larger than the other and propagates efficiently without interacting with structural defects and lattice phonons. This requires a peculiar combination of properties where some electrons are free to move, while other electrons and lattice phonons are prevented from doing so, a situation referred to as “phonon glass electron crystal”.

 

Our work has been aimed at identifying the types of electronic states that are conducive to high thermoelectric performance. We discovered that when states with conical Dirac-type dispersion coexist with “heavy” states at the Fermi level, the power factor can reach very large values due to the much longer average paths of the high-energy Dirac electrons in comparison with the lower-energy “heavy” ones. This situation exists in bulk materials that belong to certain symmetry groups, such as CoSi, and is enhanced in two-dimensional materials such as MoSi monolayers. Our work on a recently discovered family of compounds from the full Heusler family shows that they have exceptional thermoelectric performance. They exhibit ultralow thermal conductivity due to very anharmonic interatomic bonds and high thermoelectric power factors due to existence of many small high-mobility pockets of charge carriers. These predictions await experimental testing. We have also answered the more general question - what types of electronic states are most likely to result in high power factors. Again, we find that a multitude of carrier pockets combined with a highly directional distribution of energies can generate the best thermoelectric performance. In ideal circumstances when combined with ultralow lattice thermal conductivity, the estimated thermoelectric efficiency can significantly exceed the current state-of-the-art. These findings will serve as a guide for experimentalists and theorists designing the next-generation of thermoelectric materials.
